isis.stitle: Recall 98302 - Adjustable Steering Column Pinch Bolt Nut GENESIS and AmTran RE Buses

recall.subject: Adjustable Steering Column Pinch Bolt Nut GENESIS and AmTran RE Buses

defect.para: This Recall applies to AmTran RE and GENESIS buses built from April 6, 1998 through May 27, 1998.
American Transportation Corporation (AmTran) has determined that a defect relating to motor vehicle safety exists in some AmTran vehicles in connection with the steering system.

The adjustable steering column is a two piece assembly with a pinch bolt and nut connecting the upper column to the lower column. The lower steering column assembly also uses a pinch bolt and nut at the steering gear and is not affected by this recall. The upper pinch bolt and nut is locate in the driver's compartment just above the driver's feet. (Reference Figure 1.) In some cases the nut on this model may not have been installed to the upper pinch bolt during the assembly process. If the nut was not installed to the pinch bolt, it is possible for the bolt to fall out and cause the lower column to separate from the upper column. If this happens, the operator of the vehicle will lose steering control.

Owners have been notified of this recall and have been directed to contact an AmTran or GENESIS dealer to make arrangements for inspection and remedy of the defect. They have also been warned not to drive their vehicle until the inspection and repair has been completed.

svcproc.title: INSPECTION AND REPAIR PROCEDURE
svcproc.para: Locate the lower shaft of the steering column, which is covered by a protective boot just below the housing under the steering wheel. The pinch bolt and nut are located approximately one inch below the joint of the sheet metal column housing and the protective boot. To determine if the nut is installed, it is recommended that the protective boot should be lowered from the upper column assembly. Refer to Figure 1 for picture aid.
Directions to lower the protective boot are as follows:

step1.para: Locate the two mounting angles, one each side, that are bolted with two bolts per angle to the upper column assembly.
Loosen the four nuts that secure the mounting angles to the dash support bracket.

Remove the two lower bolts (one each side) that secure the mounting angles to the upper column assembly. NOTE: The lower set of these bolts also retain the protective boot and the left lower bolt also secures the turn signal wiring harness clamp. This bolt is 1/8 of an inch longer than the bolt on the right side and its length is critical to accommodate the harness clamp.
Loosen, but do not remove, the remaining upper two bolts (one each side) that secure the mounting angles to the upper column assembly.
While spreading the plastic bottom end cover, lower the boot from the upper column assembly until you can visually see or feel the nut on the upper pinch bolt.

step2.para: If there is no nut assembled to this pinch bolt or no bolt and nut assembly, install the nut or nut and bolt as specified in the material section of this notification. Torque to 55 - 60 ft-lbs.
If the original equipment nut is assembled to the pinch bolt it should look like the "Properly Torqued" illustration in Figure 2 and no repair is required.

If the nut is in place, but has not been properly tightened, the nut will have a plastic collar in place and both halves of the nut will be intact. Use sufficient torque, applied to the outboard half of the nut, to cause outboard half of the nut to break away.

svcproc.title: RE-ASSEMBLE

step1.para: Slide the protective boot onto the upper column assembly under the plastic bottom end cover, making sure that the holes in the protective boot line up with the lower set of holes used to mount the mounting angles.
Place the column back to its original location between the two mounting angles.

Carefully re-install the two lower bolts making sure that the longer bolt (1/8 of an inch) is inserted through the turn signal wiring harness clamp and into the lower left hole. Torque these four bolts to 17 - 23 ft-lbs. (101 - 108 Nm).
Retighten the four nuts that secure the mounting angles to the dash support bracket. Torque these four nuts to 17 - 23 ft-lbs. (101 - 108 Nm).

Start engine with the parking brakes applied. Make several turns with the steering wheel to make sure that there is no interference with the bolts you have just installed and no interference between the protective boot and the joint that was inspected.

svcproc.para: Complete and return the owners' postage-paid "AUTHORIZATION FOR RECALL SERVICE" card checking box #1 or #2.

partsinfo.para: Cost of purchasing new "grade 8" lock nuts and the cost of the wheel seals should be added to the recall claim.

note.para: Shear type nut is used in plant assembly operation only and is not available in service parts. Use dealer Service Parts inventory for the above parts if required.

entry.para: Inspect and install pinch bolt nut.
Install Campaign Identification Label and complete documentation.

responuscan.para:
Proceed immediately to make necessary correction to units in inventory. As a precaution, you should not operate any of the vehicles subject to this recall campaign until they have been inspected for the presence of the nut assembled to the pinch bolt. In the event that the nut is missing, repairs must be made before the vehicle is driven. All inventory vehicles subject to this recall campaign must be corrected prior to sale, transfer or delivery.
If vehicles have been sold or transferred and you are in receipt of Customer Notification Letters and Authorization for Recall Service cards for those vehicles, transfer location or customer must be notified from your dealer location.

The National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act, as amended, provides that each vehicle that is subject to a vehicle recall campaign must be adequately repaired within a reasonable time after the owner has tendered it for repair. A failure to adequately repair within 60 days after a tender of a vehicle is prima facie evidence of failure to repair within a reasonable time. If the condition is not adequately repaired within 60 days, the owner may be entitled to replacement with an identical or reasonable equivalent vehicle at no charge, or to a refund of the purchase price less a reasonable allowance for depreciation.

In order to avoid having to replace an owner's vehicle or refund the purchase price, every effort must be made to promptly schedule an appointment with each owner to repair his or her vehicle as soon as possible.
